results.headline: Desperate Lives Crisscross in Train-Hopping Journey

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sin Nombre

results.summary_short: The caressing, honeyed light in “Sin Nombre” beautifies and softens every ugly moment in this equivocating story about geographic and moral border crossings.

results.headline: Best Man Wanted. Must Be Rush Fan.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Love You, Man

results.summary_short: “I Love You, Man” is a fitfully funny comedy that owes much to Judd Apatow.

results.headline: Extinction Looms! Stop the Aliens!

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Knowing

results.summary_short: With “Knowing,” it’s probably not a good sign when, at a screening, spectacles of mass death and intimations of planetary destruction are met with hoots and giggles.

results.headline: The High Cost of Dignity: Recalling the Troubles in Stark Detail

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hunger

results.summary_short: With calm, deliberate attention — an approach at once compassionate and dispassionate — “Hunger” explores physical extremity and political extremism.

results.headline: Futons for Sale (Depression Is Free)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bob Funk

results.summary_short: “Bob Funk” looks like a comedy, acts like a comedy and sounds like a comedy, but it isn’t funny.

results.headline: Drunk, Randy, Jealous and Poetic

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Edge of Love

results.summary_short: Booze and jealousy make a toxic cocktail, one that’s heavily imbibed with much self-lacerating gusto in the grim British drama “The Edge of Love.”

results.headline: All the Pretty Delusions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Super Capers

results.summary_short: “Super Capers” is a black hole of a comedy, from which no joke, idea or molecule of entertainment can escape.

results.headline: Old-Timer Has Fans Falling at His Feet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Buck Howard

results.summary_short: “The Great Buck Howard” is an agreeable show business satire with a warm heart.

results.headline: A Life Videotaping Life Has Become a Movie

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Feature

results.summary_short: Michel Auder has been making videos longer than almost anyone, and that alone makes the work of this underappreciated artist and filmmaker worth attending to.

results.headline: Portrait of a Fashion King: Palazzos, Pugs and Peons

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Valentino: The Last Emperor

results.summary_short: Watching “Valentino: The Last Emperor” is a little like gorging on chocolate and Champagne.

results.headline: Line Between Real Life and Acting, Fuzzily Drawn

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alexander the Last

results.summary_short: “Alexander the Last,” a 72-minute series of loosely connected scenes, follows an actress’s lurching conversations and tentative gestures in life and the theater.

results.headline: Creatively Connected Through Dance and Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Carmen & Geoffrey

results.summary_short: “Carmen & Geoffrey” chronicles the personal and creative careers of two dancers.

results.headline: Upended by Downsizing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tokyo Sonata

results.summary_short: Though “Tokyo Sonata” looks like a family melodrama, there is more than a touch of horror to its story of a downsized salaryman.

results.headline: Death’s Door
results.display_title: The Last House on the Left

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last House on the Left

results.summary_short: “The Last House on the Left” is a study of operatic vengeance and dueling family values.

results.headline: Adventures in the Raw New World
results.display_title: Severed Ways: The Norse Discovery of America

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Severed Ways: The Norse Discovery of America

results.summary_short: The clang of swords mixes with the sounds of the whispering wind in “Severed Ways: The Norse Discovery of America.”

results.headline: One Wish Before Dying, but Plenty of Obstacles

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cake Eaters

results.summary_short: In “The Cake Eaters” superior acting elevates a small, overcrowded ensemble piece set in rural upstate New York into something a little deeper.

results.headline: Save the Cute Little Extraterrestrials! Save the Earth!

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Race to Witch Mountain

results.summary_short: Such folks will not find much to groove on in “Race to Witch Mountain, ” but it will amuse some of their young counterparts until summertime.

results.headline: Trouble in Ireland

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Waiting For Dublin

results.summary_short: “Waiting for Dublin” is great to look at, if not so much to listen to or think about.

results.headline: Bonding Amid Blood Splatters: Two Sisters and Their Messy Lives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sunshine Cleaning

results.summary_short: A better title for “Sunshine Cleaning,” directed by Christine Jeffs from a script by Megan Holley, would be “Sundance Recycling.”

results.headline: Centerfold Sentiments

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss March

results.summary_short: Mostly“Miss March” feels tame, right down to the film’s softhearted message of true love.
